name: Category I tracing
management:
- # ctx in 10 minute period averaged over a 30 minute period 
- normal ≤ 5 ctx in 10 min (averaged over 30 min) 
- tachysystole > 5 ctx per 10 min 
- ctx duration, intensity, and relaxation time between ctx also important

- the approximate mean FHR rounded to increments of 5 bpm during 10 minute window, excluding accels, decels, and periods of marked FHR variability (> 25 bpm).
- bradycardia: baseline < 110 bpm.
- tachycardia: baseline > 160 bpm.

name: Category III tracing
management:
- fluctuations in baseline that are irregular in amplitude and frequency
- visually quantified as amplitude from peak-to-trough in bpm.
- absent: undetectable change in amplitude
- minimal: amplitude range ≤ 5 bpm
- moderate: amplitude range 6-25 bpm
- marked: amplitude range > 25 bpm
details:
- determined in 10 minute window, excluding accels and decels.
- no distinction is made between short-term variability ('beat-to-beat') and long-term variability, because in actual practice they are visually determined as a unit.

name: Tachysystole
management:
- visually abrupt increase in FHR, < 30 seconds from onset to peak of accel
- accel must peak ≥ 15 bpm above baseline and last ≥ 15 seconds from onset to return to baseline
- accel ≥ 2 minutes is prolonged
- accel ≥ 10 minutes is baseline change
- before 32 weeks gestational age, definition accel as above except 10 bpm rise and 10 second duration qualify.

name: Minimal variability
management:
- visually apparent usually symmetric gradual decrease and return of FHR associated with a uterine contraction
- gradual FHR decrease defined as ≥ 30 seconds from onset to nadir
- decrease measured from onset to nadir
- nadir occurs same time as ctx peak
- in most cases, onset, nadir, recovery of decel are coincident with start, peak, and end of ctx, respectively.

name: Intermittant variable decels
management:
- visually apparent abrupt decrease in FHR
- abrupt FHR decrease defined as < 30 seconds from onset to nadir
- decrease measured from onset to nadir
- FHR decrease ≥ 15 bpm, lasts 15 seconds to 2 minutes duration
- when variable decels associated with ctx, their onset, depth, and duration commonly vary with successive ctx.

name: Recurrent variable decels
management:
- visually apparent usually symmetric gradual decrease and return of FHR associated with a uterine contraction
- gradual FHR decrease defined as ≥ 30 seconds from onset to nadir
- size measured from onset to nadir; note that unlike variable decelerations which must be ≥ 15 bpm below baseline, the ACOG definition cites no minimum size of descent for late decelerations
- decel is delayed, with nadir occurring after peak of contraction
- in most cases, onset, nadir, recovery of late decel occur after start, peak, and end of ctx respectively.

name: Recurrent late decels
management:
- visually apparent decrease in FHR below baseline
- FHR decrease is ≥ 15 bpm
- decel duration is ≥ 2 minutes and < 10 minutes (≥ 10 minutes makes the decel a change of FHR baseline and potentially fetal bradycardia if FHR < 110)

name: Fetal tachychardia
management: - decels are recurrent when they occur with ≥ 50% of ctx in any 20 minute window; decels occuring with < 50% of ctx are considered intermittent.
details: - several terms and findings require further research investigation to determine their predictive value: slow return of FHR after end of ctx; biphasic decels; tachycardia after variable decels; accels preceeding and/or following decels, sometimes called 'shoulders' and 'overshoots'; fluctuations in FHR in the trough of the decel; grading systems for depth and duration of decels.

name: Prolonged decel/bradycardia
management:
- specific FHR pattern defined as having a visually apparent, smooth sine wave-like undulating pattern in FHR baseline with a cycle frequency of 3-5 per minute that persists for ≥ 20 minutes.
- sinusoidal pattern is definitive for Category III tracing interpretation
